Description: Tondo sherd (mended from two fragments) of Attic red-figured pottery kylix with part of stem; interior: narrow reserved band around tondo, which depicts nude crouching warrior to right, looking back (only lower legs missing, wearing helmet with crest, holding spear in left hand and round shield decorated with bucranium, in right hand); reserved underside of stem. Nonsense lettering on shield. Relief contour.
Producer name: Attributed to the Manner of: The Pithos Painter
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The attribution is in the first edition of ARV (118), but not the second.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 513, no. C83)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 48, pl. XXVII, no. 9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1520)
